title: Adab d) in Ṣūfism
source_editors: Kate Fleet, Gudrun Krämer, Denis Matringe, John Nawas, and Devin J. Stewart
content:
Adab 
 in Ṣūfism includes the exposition, delimitation, and interpretation of rules and norms pertaining to individual conduct, social etiquette, and spiritual comportment. It represents a perennial theme in Ṣūfī literature, its significance being well captured in an oft-quoted aphorism attributed to the early Malāmatī master ofNīshāpūr, Abū Ḥafṣ al-Ḥaddād (d. c. 265/878–9), “the whole of Ṣūfīsm is proper manners: for every mystical moment (waqt) there is a manner, and for every mystical stage (maqām) a manner” (al-Sulamī, Ṭabaqāt al-ṣūfiyya , ed. Muṣṭafa ʿAbd al-Qādir ʿAṭā (Beirut 1998), 106). Indeed, as indicated by a wide array of anecdotes and apophthegms attributed to Ṣūfī paragons from the late second/eighth through the early fourth/tenth century in Ṣūfī biographical compendia, the ascetic, pietistic, and mystico-theological circles, which proved formative to the early Ṣūfī movement, showed a marked concern for matters connected with proper manners and behaviour. The notion of a close relationship between mannered behaviour and spiritual realisation is particularly well evinced in the teachings of the noted proto-Ṣūfī moraliser and psychologist of Iraq al-Ḥārith al-Muḥāsibī (d. 243/857).

In both term and concept, discussions of adab figure prominently in the normative Ṣūfī literature produced between the late fourth/tenth through the final quarter of the fifth/eleventh century. In the main, such discussions are apologetic in intent, designed to show how the behavioural norms of the Ṣūfīs are rooted in perfect adherence to Qurʾānic dictate and the emulation of the exemplary behaviour of the Prophet and the pious forbearers. Thus, the oft-quoted handbook of the Ṣūfīcontroversialist of Khurāsān Abū Naṣr al-Sarrāj (d. 378/988) contains a lengthy section devoted to enumerating the distinguishing manners (ādāb) of the Ṣūfīs across a wide range of activities, from their attentive interiorising performance of the obligatory religious duties of Islam, to their habits of travel, companionship, dress, and eating, and from their practice of voluntary poverty to their conduct in matters of social intercourse, discipleship, illness, and death ( K. al-lumaʿ , 136–93). Much the same can be found in a number of the surviving works of the noted Ṣūfī scholar of Nīshāpūr Abū ʿAbd al-Raḥmān al-Sulamī (d. 412/1021), two of which are devoted specifically to matters of Ṣūfī adab : the Kitāb ādāb al-ṣuḥba (“Book of the manners of companionship”) and the Jawāmiʿ ādāb al-ṣūfiyya (“Collected manners of the Ṣūfīs”).

Reminiscent of the formulation of al-Muḥāsibī, the classical Ṣūfī discourse on adab is predicated on the idea that the methodical cultivation of proper modes of comportment serves a productive purpose, namely providing the aspirant with a self-effacing, life-oriented framework that aids in his battle against instinctual inborn drives, inclinations, desires, and fancies, all of which estrange the spirit from God. Embedded in this discourse is the idea that proper behaviours possess both an outer, praxic dimension (ādāb al-ẓāhir) , as well as an inner, attitudinal dimension (ādāb al-bāṭin) . Only the Ṣūfīs can claim to achieve a full synthesis. This idea is perhaps best expressed in the anonymous late fourth/tenth century Kitāb ādāb al-mulūk (“Book of the manners of kings”). Arguing that the Ṣūfīs' approach to adab is that of a rare spiritual elite, the author discusses at length their particular “royal manners” with regard to both apparent externalities, such as dress, food, and vocation, as well as to psycho-spiritual states and moral qualities, such as ecstasy, generosity, and informality. Although much more guarded, this attitude is reflected to a certain degree in the discussion of diverse points of ādāb related to basic ritual and social acts by the celebrated theologian, jurist, mystic, and religious reformer al-Ghazālī (d. 505/1111) in the first and second quarters of his massive Iḥyāʾ ʿulūm al-dīn (“Revivification of the religious sciences”).

The increasing formalisation of Ṣūfī institutions beginning in the sixth/twelfth century brought with it a blossoming of Ṣūfī adab literature, especially of works of the ādāb al-murīdīn (“manners of aspirants”) genre. Focused largely on the concerns of day-to-day life in and around the increasingly ubiquitous Ṣūfī ribāṭ s and khānqāh s (residential facilities), this literature is decidedly practical in nature, often directed at furnishing novices with a template of behaviour befitting their status as disciples of a Ṣūfī master. Among the earliest such works, drawing upon the Kitāb al-iqtiṣād (“Book of the golden mean”) of the fourth/tenth-century Persian Ṣūfī Ibn Khafīf of Shiraz (d. 371/982), is Kitāb ādāb al-murīdīn (“Book of aspirants' manners”) of the ribāṭ -directing Ṣūfī master of Baghdad, Abū l-Najīb al-Suhrawardī (d. 563/1168). It is a practical handbook of Ṣūfī adab that includes a long list of special “dispensations” ( rukhaṣ , sing. rukhṣa ) for affiliates unable to shoulder the demands of full-time discipleship (recap. in Bākharzī, Fuṣūṣ , 272–89). In both substance and spirit, this work provided a pattern upon which Abū l-Najīb's nephew and student, ʿUmar al-Suhrawardī (d. 632/1234), elaborated a systematic formulation of Ṣūfī adab in his influential handbook, ʿAwārif al-maʿārif (“Benefits of intimate knowledge,” chaps. 31–55; parallels in al-Jīlānī, al-Ghunya , 2:279–305), a detailed system of behaviours embracing nearly all aspects of life concerned with wayfaring on the Ṣūfī path (Ohlander, Sufism , 187–247). In addition to quickly becoming a popular vade mecum for both the Suhrawardiyya and early Chishtiyya orders, the influence of al-Suhrawardī's treatment of adab is apparent in discussions of the same in his son ʿImād al-Dīn's (d. 655/1257) Kitāb zād al-musāfir wa-l-adab al-ḥāḍir (“Book of the guest's provisions and the resident's comportment”), the Mukhtaṣar fī ādāb al-ṣūfiyya (“Précis on the good manners of the Ṣūfīs”) by the eponymous founder of the Kubrāwiyya order Najm al-Dīn Kubrā (d. 618/1221; wrongly attributed to ʿAbdallāh-i Anṣārī), the Miṣbāḥ al-hidāya (“The lamp of guidance”) of the Persian Ṣūfī ʿIzz al-Dīn Kāshānī (d. 735/1334–5), and the lengthy Fuṣūṣ al-ādāb (“Bezels of good manners”) of the Kubrawī master Yaḥyā Bākharzī (d. 736/1335–6). The similarities between the prescriptions for Ṣūfī aspirants in these works and those discussed over two centuries earlier by the Ṣūfī theorist and historian al-Hujwīrī (d. c. 465/1072) are telling ( Kashf , 432–79).

As with many resonating terms within the tradition, Ṣūfī theorists have often treated adab in its spiritual and metaphorical dimensions as well, typically speaking of it in terms of three broad types, viz., as proper comportment vis-à-vis divine law (adab al-sharīʿa) , as proper comportment vis-à-vis others (adab al-khidma/al-muʿāmalāt) , and as adab al-ḥaqq , or proper comportment vis-à-vis God (e.g., al-Iṣfahānī, Nahj al-khāṣṣ , s.v. “ adab ”; al-Hujwīrī, Kashf , 433–36; ʿAbdallāh-i Anṣārī, Ṣad maydān , ed. M. Najafī(Tehran 1383), 69–70; Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya, Madārij , 2:376; and, al-Shushtarī, al-Risālat al-ʿilmiyya , ed. Muḥammad al-ʿAdlūnī al-Idrīsī (Casablanca 2004), 160). To this list, the renowned Iberian Ṣūfī visionary Ibn ʿArabī (d. 638/1240) added a fourth: adab al-ḥaqīqa , or proper comportment vis-à-vis the divine reality ( Futūḥāt , 2:284–85; but cf. idem, K. iṣṭilāḥ al-ṣūfiyya , in Rasāʾil Ibn ʿArabī (Beirut 1997), 530). For his part, Jalāl al-Dīn Rūmī (d. 672/1273), the beloved Persian mystical poet settled at Konya, often speaks of adab as a matter of elemental necessity in relation to the acts of both God and man ( Mathnawī-yi maʿnawī , ed. R. A. Nicholson (London 1925–34), bk. 1, lines 78–9, bk. 2, lines. 3218–24, bk. 3, lines 350, 3606–9, 3677–81, and bk. 6, lines. 1513, 2583).

Formulaic discussions of adab are typical in most later Ṣūfī literature, especially in contexts concerning the particularised rites, rules, regulations, and mystico-ascetic practices associated with individual Ṣūfī orders.
